skos:Concept.skos:definition: Hautbois du Couserans, France
Instrument with free reeds (sort of harmonium) invented by Christian Dietz around 1830

Compact large single-headed cylindrical drum with feet carved out of the base, and which is beated with a stick. Played by of the Mbosi-Koyo people in the Cuvette region of Republic of the Congo. Geometrical engravings decorate the body. Used in the Odaki (OdaKé) lovers dance, and in the Ekongo warriors dance

Guimbarde originaire du Cambodge. Il en existe deux sortes : la première, en métal, possède une languette hétéroglotte alourdie à son extrémité par une boule de cire. La deuxième, fabriquée en bambou, a une languette idioglotte
Balafon, played in ensemble (solo, bass, accompaniments) of the Nzime people in the Sangha region, close to the Cameroun border
Hautbois cylindrique à anche double idioglotte, présent en Chine
Polish folk double bass; size not standarized

A kind of trumpet (straight labrosone) with a conical profile, made from a trunk of a young tree that is cut along in two halves, then each is hollowed, and finally both are put back together with the help of pitch; formerly used for apotropaic purposes (while making the ritual uproar) and signalling (shepherds, fishermen, firefighters, to signal the beginning of rituals and ceremonies); nowadays as part of folk revival; a symbol of Cassubians' ethnic identity (Kaszuby, the region of Poland)
Flûte oblique d'Arménie, d'origine pastorale et semblable au blur turc
Cornemuse du Val d'Aran, sans bourdon et à anche simple
Large cylindrical footed drum from the Koyo and Banguele of the Cuvette region (Makoua) in the Republic of Congo. Used fot popular festivitie
In Balinese culture, the Calung is actually a metallophonic instrument that has a one-octave range, and is generally utilized to play mid-range melodies
A musical tool used to make the so-called musical racket; nowadays used as percussion instrument in folk bands in Kaszuby (Cassubia) Poland, and is a symbol of the region's musical identity
Flûte originaire du Laos et du Vietnam, similaire au bawu
Vessel rattle of the Mobsi-Makwa people of Republic of the Congo. Made of a small calebash, of which the neck is closed with a cork
Rattle made of a rectangular flat dried fruit, used by the Teke-Ngangoulou people of the Plateaux region in Republic of the Congo to accompany their dances
Played in the vertical position (hung over the shoulder on a string or leaned on the knee); players applied side string shortening (the so-called fingernail technique)
Cornemuse de Galice
Elongated hourglass drum from the Nuni people in Burkina Faso

Pedal accordion, bellows connected to the instrument with a two-piece pipe. After World War I the accordion became a popular component of polish folk bands (together with the violin and the drum); the pedal type being especially popular in Mazovia on the right side of the Vistula river (the region of Kurpie and the area of Garwolin), to some degree also in Podlasie (Podlachia)
Hautbois sri lankais
North African term for an oblique rim-blown flute
Chad ensemble of calebashes, the biggest one used as recipient filled with water in which the two smaller ones are beaten
Flûte oblique égyptienne en bambou à 3 sections et 6 trous de jeu
Rectangular 'raft' rattle from the Mijikenda people in Kenya, consisting of a tray-shaped box made from made of straw stems bound together, with seeds inside
Sanza of the Teke, Kongo and Bembe people of the Republic of the Congo. Five to eight lamellae in metal or bamboo, mounted on a box or a board
Cylindrical friction drum of the Kongo people of the Bouenza region (Mouyondzi) in the Republic of Congo, Used to accompany religious and laic songs
Large side blown anthopomorphic wooden natural trumpet of the Kongo-Bembe people of Republic of the Congo

A polish bagpipe from Podhale region. A mouth blown instrument; four voices; has a short triple chanter-drone pipe (5+1 fingerholes) and a long drone pipe ending in a hyperbolic bell (of a clarinet type); all pipes with cylindrical bores; bag made from a goat's whole skin; formerly played solo (by shepherds, wandering musicians), nowadays in folk revival, sometimes included in Podhale bands. The ability to build and play the Podhale bagpipe, or goat, were included on the National List of Intangible Cultural Heritage

A polish bagpipe with low tuning and elegiac sound; formerly used during the ritual part of the wedding ceremony together with mazanki, after World War II reactivated in the S. Moniuszko Music School in Zbąszyń and in the folk revival

A bagpipe with 16th c. roots; the biggest of Polish bagpipes with the lowest tuning and an elegiac sound; traditional element of folk bands in west Greater Poland (along with violins and, after World War I, an E-flat clarinet)
Conical drum of the Teke-Kukuya people of the republic of Congo

A portable xylophone of the Sara, Barma and neighbouring peoples of southern Chad. The keys are strung together each above a gourd resonator, which can be either curved or staight and is fitted with a mirliton made of a fish bladder, bat's wing or spider's web

A kind of horn (conical profile), made from a branch that is cut along in two halves, then each is hollowed, and finally both are put back together with the help of pitch and metal hoops; formerly used as a signal instrument (mainly in herding); since 19th c. used during Advent and watchnight service on Christmas Eve (mainly in north-east and east regions of Poland); nowadays as part of folk revival
Side blown horn of the Bomitaba people in the Likouala region of Republic of the Congo. Made from an antilope horn
Rudimentary xylophone of the Bomitaba people of the Likouala region in Republic of the Congo. Played on the ground, with 5 lamellae

Small fiddle of the Wielkopolska (Greater Poland), region of Poland. An instrument with medieval roots; before World War I used in Poland during the ritual part of the wedding (wedding feast) together with the wedding bagpipe (Kozioł weselny / Kozioł biały); after World War II reactivated in the S. Moniuszko Music School in Zbąszyń; now used in the folk revival, too. Almost entirely carved from one piece of wood; three strings; one of bridge's feet longer, going through an opening in the top plate and resting on the back plate, functioning as a soundpost
Hautbois cylindrique turc
Vessel rattle of the Teke-Ngangoulou people of the Plateaux region in Republic of the Congo. Made of a small calebash, filled with grains of which the neck is closed with a cork

Rattle of the Mbosi people in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo. Two or more small dried gourds are mounted on a stick and serve as vessel rattles. Used by the griot to accompany his praise songs

Vessel rattle made from a big dried longitudinal bean-like fruit, from the Teke-Kukuya people in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo. Called Oumouaka by the Pygmee people of Republic of the Congo
Iron double bell, often with a raphia woven handle from the Teke peoples in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo
Vessel rattle made from a big dried longitudinal bean-like fruit, from the Teke people in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo
Slit drum from the Kongo and Bembe peoples of the Congo's. Used to accompany the Mufueti or Masoko dance. It is crescent shaped, played in pairs, and associated with religious and magical practices
Single or double woven rattle with handle from the Kongo and Bembe people of the Bouenza region in the south of Republic of the Congo
Scraped slit stick of the Kongo, Bembe and Suku peoples of the Congo's. It is a hollowed stick or bamboo tube with a lengthwise slit
Hautbois droit ou courbe du Népal
Vessel rattle made from a big dried longitudinal bean-like fruit, from the Teke-Nangoulou people in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo
Side blown horn of the Teke people in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo. Made from an antelope horn. Protects against lightning and serves as a means of communication
Side blown horn of the Kongo and Bembe people of the Bouenza region in the south of Republic of the Congo. Made from an antelope horn. 'Mvouri' = 'antelope'. Used to accompany songs calling for rain
Side blown antelope horn of the Mbosi and Kongo people of the Congo's

Longitudinal wooden drum from the Kongo and Vili people of the Kouilou region (Pointe-Noire) in the Republic of the Congo. Played horizontally, with a handle carved in the wooden sound box. Used for the healing ritual called ' n'assi ', for popular festivities and also used for communication

Small double-skin barrel drum of the Kongo-Vili and Kongo-Bembe peoples of the Kouilou and Bouenza regions in the lower Republic of the Congo. Both skins (goath or antilope) are laced together over the sound box with woven chords
Cylindro-concial drum of the Konda and Yembe peoples of the DRC. The name is also used for the footed conical drum of the Kongo and Bembe peoples of the Republic of Congo
Barrel drum of the Banda-Ngbugu in Central African Republic

Large single-headed barrel drum with feet carved out of the base, and which is beated with a stick. Played by the Mbosi-Makwa people in the Republic of the Congo. Used in the Amin celebration dance and lullaby. Cf. Angoho of the Mbosi-Koyo people
Portable eight plaque bass xylophone from the Bomitaba people of the Likouala region in the north of the Republic of the Congo
Bow lute (5 bows) of the Kongo-Bembe people of the Republic of Congo
Rattles made of small dried fruits strung to a strap, from the Mbosi-Makwa people in the Cuvette region of Republic of the Congo
Compact footed barrel drum from the Mbosi people of the Plateaux region in the Republic of the Congo.

Solid cylindrical (sometimes barrel or conical) drum (with or without feet carved out from the base) from the Teke-Ngangoulou people of the Plateau (Gamboma) region in the Republic of the Congo. Used to accompany songs in the ritual dances and popular festivities

Bow lute of the Teke people in Central Africa, the Congo's and Gabon. Five fibre strings are mounted almost perpendicular to a large sound box, on which geometrical decorations are engraved and burned. A buzzing effect is produced by metal jingles on the string-bearers
Lute from the Teke People in the Republic of Congo. Used to accompany ritual and popular dances

Rattle of the Kongo -Bembe and Kongo-Minkengue people in the Bouenza region of Republic of the Congo. Two or more small dried gourds are mounted on a stick and serve as vessel rattles. Used by the griot to accompany his praise songs
Bell of the Teke people in the Cuvette and Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo. Made of buffle horns

Small side blown horn of the Teke people in Gabon and the Republic of the Congo. Made from an antelope horn. Serves as a means of communication and to call the spirits of the ancestors. 'Ntsiemi' means 'horn' in the Teke language
Bowl lyre of the Luo people from Kenya
Large bowl lyre of the Gusii people in Kenya, with large flat bridge
Vessel rattle of the Mobsi-Koyo people of Republic of the Congo. Made of a small calebash, of which the neck is closed with a cork
Plain cylindrical footed drum from the Mbosi-Koyo people of the Cuvette region (Owando) in the Republic of Congo. Used in a dance to celebrate the birth of twins called 'Okera'
Goblet drum from the Mbosi ans Makwa people of the Cuvette region (Makoua) in the Republic of the Congo. Used in the Ondzambé dance
Vessel rattle made from a big dried longitudinal bean-like fruit, from the Teke people in the Republic of Congo. Called Otsara by the Pygmee people of Republic of the Congo

Small single-headed square frame drum from the Teke people in the Republic of the Congo. The skin is nailed to a robust wooden frame. Held between the legs, the pitch can be changed by the pressure of the heel on the skin. Used to accompany the danse 'okilidzéké' of the young people. Also used in the 1920's in the maringa, an urban music style attributed amonst other to the Loango region on the French Congolese coast, and described as 'Europeanized' since it included also accordion and rhythms borrowed from polkas, marches, hymns, etc. The patenge is also played to accompany the rumba
Hautbois du Cambodge

A seasonal, polish folk instrument, made in the spring; would become porous and unplayable when it dried out; formerly a signal instrument (used by shepherds), often played by children, nowadays sometimes made as a music toy; body made from a spirally rolled piece of willow bark, fastened with a thorn ('przetyczka'); it should have a double reed ('bekas'), also made of willow bark, in the inlet
Clarinette indonésienne
Orgue à bouche du peuple Hmong
Mâchoire racle

A ritual music tool; made of a handle (wrapped with string) with three branches, each with a clapper bell; an attribute of ritual wedding figures (marshal, best men); used in the Lubelskie province, Poland; it was shaken to produce ringing to accompany singing
Cornemuse roussillonnaise
Hautbois cylindrique de la province de Sind (Pakistan)
Bell hung on sheep's neck as a signalization (formerly also for apotropaic purposes)
Compact cylindrical footed drum from the Teke-Kukuya people in the Republic of Congo. Used to accompany the song during the ritual dances and popular festivities
Hautbois des Balkans

Small polish fiddle. Suka is known thanks to an item from the Biłgoraj area, Poland, shown at the First Polish Music Exhibition in Warsaw in 1888 (written accound by Jan Karłowicz, sketch by Tadeusz Dowgird, 1888, watercolour painting by Wojciech Gerson, 1896); in the second half of the 19th c., and possibly at the beginning of the 20th c. it was used in the south of the Lublin region (Biłgoraj area), probably accompanied by a single-skin drum; now used by artists of the folk revival; suka is played in the vertical position (hung over the shoulder on a string or leaned on the knee); players applied side string shortening (so-called fingernail technique)
Hautbois de Catalogne

Wooden double bell of the Kongo-Vili people in the Kouilou region near the Atlantic coast in the Republic of the Congo. Geometrical decoration engraved and burned. Used by the Nganga, healer and spiritualist, the hourglass shaped double bell is liked to Nkisi cult worship and is used during songs and dances to treat the ill. It is also played during twin birth ceremonies
Hautbois de Catalogne
Side-blown flute from the Peul people in Senegal. Named after the cane's name out of which it is made. Mouthpiece made of wax. Often covered in colourful textile

Conical or cylindrical drum of the Teke people of the Plateaux region in Republic of the Congo, made from the holow trunk of a tree, on to one opening of which is nailed an antelope skin. The nails are covered by a strip made from caoutchouc
